questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female (46XX) is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text: Mark the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium: (FMGE Jan 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba → Lochia Rubra

options.label: B
options.text: Lochia Serosa → Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba

options.label: C
options.text: Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba

options.label: D
options.text: Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba → Lochia Serosa

questions.correct_answer: C. Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lochia Rubra

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lochia is vaginal discharge after delivery.
  • • It is composed of sloughed off decidua, blood, necrotic debris and secretions of the cervixand vagina.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of lochia during the puerperium is Lochia Rubra (red, first 3-4 days), Lochia Serosa (yellowish-brownish, 5-9 days), and Lochia Alba (white, lasts 10-28 days).
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th Edition page 170
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th Edition page 170

questions.text: What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? ( INICET MAY 2022) LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs. Bladder and bowel involvement. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central cord lesions, such as syringomyelia, typically present with LMN signs in the upper limbs, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and can involve bladder and bowel dysfunction, but they do not typically affect the posterior tracts

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with a history of burn wound on the lower limb. His wound is given in the picture. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Marjolin's Ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds, including long-standing burn wounds.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: All the following side effects of lithium, likely to occur after 1 year of treatment except- (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tardive Dyskinesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While tremors, hypothyroidism, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are potential side effects of lithium that may occur after a year of treatment, tardive dyskinesia is typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications.

questions.text: What is the airway management of choice in a patient with maxillofacial trauma after a road traffic accident? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tracheostomy is the preferred airway management technique in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma. This approach is chosen because severe facial injuries can make other forms of intubation difficult or impossible due to anatomical disruptions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Orotracheal Intubation: Typically the first-line method in emergency airway management, it may be contraindicated or challenging in maxillofacial trauma due to the risk of causing further injury.
  • • Option B. Orotracheal Intubation:
  • • Option C. Nasotracheal Intubation: Avoided in maxillofacial injuries due to the risk of creating a false passage or worsening a basal skull fracture.
  • • Option C. Nasotracheal Intubation:
  • • Option D. Oxygen Therapy: While important for providing oxygen, it does not secure the airway and is insufficient in cases of airway compromise.
  • • Option D. Oxygen Therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In severe maxillofacial trauma where the airway is compromised, an emergency tracheostomy is often necessary if orotracheal intubation is not feasible or safe due to the extent of the injuries.

questions.text: An unknown substance consumption leads to tachycardia and red coloured halo. This is seen with consumption of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LSD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The consumption of an unknown substance leading to tachycardia and ared-coloured halo can be associated with both cocaine and LSD. However, based on the limited information provided in the question, LSD is the more likely answer.
  • • Both cocaine and LSD can cause sympathomimetic features such as tachycardia, sweating, increased heart rate, and increased blood pressure. However, these symptoms are generally more pronounced with cocaine consumption. On the other hand, hallucinogenic features, such as hallucinations, are more commonly associated with LSD use.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option. A. Cannabis : Cannabis has minimal physiological effects and is unlikely to cause tachycardia and sweating.
  • • Option. A. Cannabis
  • • Option. B. Crack/Cocaine: If the question had emphasized intense tachycardia, intense sweating, and other sympathomimetic symptoms, cocaine would have been the more appropriate answer. However, based on the given information, LSD is the better fit.
  • • Option. B. Crack/Cocaine:
  • • Option. D. Heroine: Heroin is a central nervous system (CNS) depressant and typically leads to bradycardia rather than tachycardia.
  • • Option. D. Heroine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both cocaine and LSD can cause sympathomimetic features like tachycardia and sweating, but these symptoms are more intense with cocaine. Hallucinations are more commonly associated with LSD. The correct answer depends on the specific details provided in the question, emphasizing either sympathomimetic or hallucinogenic features.

questions.text: Identify the marked segment of liver. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. V

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments according to the Couinaud classification

questions.text: Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021) Ilizarov Uniplanar frame with one rod Biplanar frame Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:
  • ➤ For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:
  • ➤ For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:
  • ➤ Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave

options.label: C
options.text: Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: Night blindness is a late feature

questions.correct_answer: D. Night blindness is a late feature
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bladder exstrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. The management involves staged surgical reconstruction, and complications include strictures, hyperchloremic acidosis, and increased risk of tumors.

questions.text: What does ‘H’ indicate in a patient presenting with a history of EHEC O157:H7? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flagella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In bacterial antigen classification, the ‘H’ antigen corresponds to flagella, which are essential for motility.

questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon performed? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Extra capsular cataract surgery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE), a larger incision (approximately 10 to 12 millimeters) is made at the limbus to remove the lens nucleus in one piece. Due to the size of this incision, suturing is necessary to close the wound properly. The suturing is typically performed using 10-0 nylon monofilament. This method can involve interrupted sutures or continuous suturing to ensure the wound is securely closed and to promote proper healing.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Phacoemulsification : This technique involves making a much smaller incision (around 3 millimeters or less) through which the lens is emulsified and aspirated. Suturing is generally not required because the small incision is self-sealing.
  • • Option A. Phacoemulsification
  • • Suturing is generally not required
  • • Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery) : This advanced technique uses a femtosecond laser to create precise incisions and to perform capsulotomy and lens fragmentation. Similar to phacoemulsification, the incisions made are small and typically do not require suturing.
  • • Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery)
  • • Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS) : In SICS, the incision size is between 6 to 8 millimeters. Depending on the quality of the incision and tunnel, suturing may or may not be required. Good surgical technique can often avoid the need for suturing.
  • • Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE) requires suturing with 10-0 nylon due to the larger incision size necessary for removing the lens nucleus in one piece.

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.
  • ➤ The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

questions.text: A patient working in an iron factory presents with visual disturbance and is found to have iron deposits in the eye. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this ocular finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Siderosis bulbi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Siderosis bulbi is caused by iron deposits in the eye, commonly seen in patients with a history of iron foreign body exposure, leading to significant ocular changes and potential blindness.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 118/78 mm Hg, Serum K + is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: - KDT 8 TH /314

questions.text: Identify the brace given in the following image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The brace shown in the image in the question is of a Milwaukee brace, which is used to treat scoliosis in adolescent children.

questions.text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 11-14 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The optimal time for determining the type of twin pregnancy through ultrasound is between 11+0 to 13+6 weeks, when the crown-rump length (CRL) is between 45 to 84 mm. This period allows for the most accurate dating and assessment of chorionicity, which is crucial for the management and outcome of twin pregnancies.
  • • Chorionicity: The type of twin pregnancy (dichorionic or monochorionic) is determined by examining the thickness of the membrane at the site of insertion. Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • • Chorionicity: The type of twin pregnancy (dichorionic or monochorionic) is determined by examining the thickness of the membrane at the site of insertion. Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • • Chorionicity:
  • • Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • • Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • • Lambda (λ) sign:
  • • Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • • Inverted T sign:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best time to determine the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2190, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2190, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.
  • • Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.
  • • Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria:
  • • Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.
  • • Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus):
  • • Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.
  • • Option D. VDRL for syphilis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: In a drowning case, primary relaxation is seen in all muscles except one group of muscles. What is this condition known as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cadaveric spasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cadaveric spasm occurs immediately after death without a phase of relaxation and is typically seen in the muscles of the hands, often indicating a struggle before death.

questions.text: What type of particles does a linear accelerator use? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) X rays

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Linear accelerators are crucial in modern oncology, allowing high precision in targeting tumors while sparing healthy tissue, using high-energy X rays derived from accelerated electrons.
  • ➤ Linear accelerators are crucial in modern oncology, allowing high precision in targeting tumors while sparing healthy tissue, using high-energy X rays derived from accelerated electrons.

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? ( INICET May 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Incisions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (e.g., systolic BP < 90 mm Hg), immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is the treatment of choice.
  • ➤ Rule of thumb: "If the patient is in shock, shock the patient."

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding increase in GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increase renal perfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increasing renal perfusion is the most effective way to increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Warfarin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an inhibitor of ATP binding cassette efflux pumps? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Verapamil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Verapamil is a known inhibitor of ATP-binding cassette transporters, particularly P-glycoprotein, and can be used to enhance the pharmacokinetics of various drugs by increasing their intracellular concentrations.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The active principle of the marking nut (Semicarpus anacardium) is Bhilawanol, used in traditional practices for its staining and toxic properties.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary healing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.
  • ➤ Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.
  • ➤ Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).
  • ➤ Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:
  • • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:
  • • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA). APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion. Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart. The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.
  • • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.
  • • Option A. Syphilis:
  • • Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.
  • • Option C. TORCH infections:
  • • Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.
  • • Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Choose the right sequence of steps in the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 17 alpha hydroxylase, 17,20 lyase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence for the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone involves the enzymes 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, 17 alpha hydroxylase, and 17,20 lyase in that specific order.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

options.label: B
options.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L

options.label: C
options.text: pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg

options.label: D
options.text: pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg

questions.correct_answer: A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient who had kidney stones removed presents with flank pain 4-5 years postoperatively and a foreign body is observed on imaging. What is the appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

questions.correct_answer: A. Endoscopy with removal of foreign body
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endoscopy with removal of foreign body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endoscopy is the appropriate procedure for the removal of a retained ureteric stent, which can cause complications if left inside the body for too long.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with dyslipidemia has persistently elevated triglyceride levels (600 mg/dL) despite treatment with rosuvastatin. What will be the next step? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with triglyceride levels above 500 mg/dL, fibrates such as gemfibrozil are the preferred treatment to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1744
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 1744

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is not used in HIV & hepatitis B co-infection? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Abacavir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the treatment of patients with HIV and hepatitis B co-infection, abacavir is not used due to its lack of efficacy against HBV. Instead, drugs like tenofovir, lamivudine, and emtricitabine, which have dual activity against both viruses, are preferred.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines
